bibl.idno: The Philip S. Hench Walter Reed/Yellow Fever Collection [manuscript] / [collected by] Philip S. Hench ; HEALTHSCI MS-1.

bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to H. Carter Redd, February 25, 1948

div1.p: Hench is anxious to have access to Carter's trunks, and so requests that Redd send them directly to his home.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to H. Carter Redd, February 25, 1948
div1.opener:
February 25, 1948
Mr. H. Carter Redd
Attorney at Law
1104 Travelers Building
Richmond, Virginia
My dear Mr. Redd:
div1.p:
Thank you so much for your letter of Feb-
ruary 10. I shall be most anxious to have the trunks
and boxes. Would you wish to express them directly
to my home, 517 4th Street, S. W.? That would save
the matter of transportation from the Clinic. I
insist upon reimbursing you for the express charges
and would appreciate it if you would let me know how
much this is.

I will be taking a little vacation but have
always found time to work at my hobby, the wonderful
story of the conquest of yellow fever.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
